encodingDesc.p: Transcriptions are encoded in TEI(P5)-conformant XML.

correction.p: Apparent errors are preserved and editorial corrections provided using SIC and CORR tags, but only where the editor conjectures that the original scribe or compositor would have recognized the instance as an error. For example, what according to modern usage is incorrect subject/verb agreement might have been deemed acceptable to a seventeenth-century scribe or compositor. All such instances are treated instead using the ORIG and REG tags. (See below.)

Corrections and annotations made within the scope of the original document either by its original authors, owners, and/or transcribers are noted using ADD tags. These annotations and may be further explained within NOTE tags, as added by the editors of this digital edition, for display within the apparatus.

normalization.p: Original spellings, abbreviations, and orthography are preserved. Where in the manuscripts a character’s status as majuscule or minuscule is ambiguous, the editor has silently chosen one or the other based on context and judgment (i.e., does not register such ambiguity in either the markup or the notes).

quotation.p: Original quotation marks, if any, are preserved.

glyph.glyphName: Handwritten 'ff' ligature, used in handwriting to represent modern F

listWit.witness: Transcription of manuscript: By Leah Knight and Wendy Wall.
Elemental Edition: By Leah Knight and Wendy Wall.
Amplified Edition: By Sarah C. E. Ross.

app.rdg: PG#Universall diſſolution made when I was with Child of my 15th Child my ſonne Johnblotted with especially large blot on “John”; blot darker on facing page I being every one thought in a Conſumption 1648

Universal Dissolutionentire, total, or global “dissolution,” meaning separation into constituent elements or atoms; disintegration, decomposition; liquefaction; laxity of morals; dispersion of an assembly (often political); death, termination., Made When I Was with Child, of my 15th Child, my Son, JohnThis is an insertion into the title, in the hand likely to be Pulter’s own. The insertion is indicated by a caret and obscured by an ink blot., I Being, Everyone Thought, in a Consumptiondisease associated with an abnormality of “humors” (in the physiology of the day, the four fluids determining health), resulting in extreme weight loss; later identified with tuberculosis; the act of decaying, 1648

Universal Dissolutionreduction to elements or atoms; disintegration; death, Made When I Was With Child of My 15th Child (My Son John)John Pulter (1648-77) was the fifteenth (and likely last) of Pulter’s children. "My Son John" is an insertion into the title, in the hand likely to be Pulter’s own. The insertion is indicated by a caret and obscured by an ink blot., I Being, Everyone Thought, in a Consumption, 1648

rdg.note: In these transcriptions we preserve as many details of the original material, textual, and graphic properties of Hester Pulter’s manuscript verse as we have found practical. Whenever possible, for instance, original spelling, punctuation, capitalization, lineation, insertions, deletions, alterations, spacing between words and lines, and indentation are all maintained; abbreviations and brevigraphs are not expanded; and superscript and subscript representations are retained. See full conventions for the transcriptions here.

The aim of the Elemental Edition is to make the poems accessible to the largest variety of readers, which involves modernizing spelling and punctuation as well as adding basic glosses. Spelling and punctuation reflect current standard American usage; punctuation highlights syntax which might otherwise be obscure. Outmoded but still familiar word forms (“thou,” “‘tis,” “hold’st”) are not modernized, and we do not modernize grammar when the sense remains legible. After a brief headnote aimed at offering a “way in” to the poem’s unique qualities and connections with other verse by Pulter or her contemporaries, the edition features a minimum of notes and interpretative framing to allow more immediate engagement with the poem. Glosses clarify synonyms or showcase various possible meanings in Pulter’s time. Other notes identify named people and places or clarify obscure material. We rely (without citation) primarily on the Oxford English Dictionary (OED), the Oxford Reference database, and the King James Version (KJV) of the Bible. When we rely on Alice Eardley’s edition of Pulter’s work, we cite her text generally (“Eardley”); other sources are cited in full. The result is an edition we consider a springboard for further work on Pulter’s poetry. See full conventions for this edition here.

note.p: My priority in editing these poems has been to modernise, and to achieve interpretative and visual clarity, in order to make the poems as accessible as possible to as wide a modern audience as is possible. Spelling is modernised, as is punctuation. Modernising the latter, in particular, often involves a significant act of editorial interpretation, but in my view this is one of the most productive areas of editorial intervention, particularly for a manuscript text such as Pulter’s where the punctuation is erratic compared to modern usage (and, indeed, compared to early modern printed texts).11. See Alice Eardley, “‘I haue not time to point yr booke … which I desire you yourselfe to doe’: Editing the Form of Early Modern Manuscript Verse”, in The Work of Form: Poetics and Materiality in Early Modern Culture, ed. Ben Burton and Elizabeth Scott-Baumann (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2014), pp. 162-178.

rdg.note: In this devotional poem, the speaker instructs her soul not to lament mortality, but to accept the eventual decay and dissolution of everything: nature, poetic fame, political power, youth, beauty, animals, civilizations, the earth, planets, and stars. In detailing how all natural and cosmological elements in the world will revert back to their “first principles” or original “cause” in the grand cycle of life, the poem provides an extensive catalogue of specific trees, plants, animals, mythological characters, ancient cities, constellations, and planets. As the title suggests, this self-reprimand—or, perhaps, self-consolation—is prompted by an illness connected with the speaker’s fifteenth pregnancy, and it does not conclude, as do many of her poems, with an affirmation of the afterlife. It seems instead focussed on the scope and scale of the unmaking of the physical world.

note.p: Pulter’s detailed title to this occasional poem indicates its context and focus. Seriously ill during her pregnancy with her fifteenth child, her son John, she addresses her own soul, fearful at the possibility of death, and reassures it by outlining the universality of “dissolution”, the death of the mortal body. Her poem progresses through an extended series of similes, comparing the end of “mortal man” to that of all other creatures and elemental things; these similes owe much to the emblematic mode of thinking that is evident in the emblem poem series later in the manuscript. For another poem written in illness during this pregnancy, see This Was Written in 1648, When I Lay in, with my Son John; and see discussion in Alice Eardley (ed.), Lady Hester Pulter: Poems, Emblems, and The Unfortunate Florinda (Toronto: Iter Inc. and Centre for Reformation and Restoration Studies, 2014), p. 16.

Like many of Pulter’s poems, “Universal Dissolution” is related to the mode of devotional complaint, in which the distressed, earthbound soul articulates its worldly grief and its yearning to be with God. Pulter’s manuscript contains several devotional complaints, such as Must I Thus Ever Interdicted Be. “Universal Dissolution,” however, is typical of many of Pulter’s other devotional poems in that it is not a complaint per se, but is cast as a response to the implicitly prior plaints of her own heart and soul. Thus the poem opens “My soul, why art thou sad ...?” The poem outlines a philosophical consolation for her heart and soul, illustrating through multiple examples that “all sublunary things decay” (line 108), and concluding “Then my unsettled soul be more resolved, / Seeing all this universe must be dissolved.” This stance exemplifies the devotional stoicism typical of Pulter’s poems, even as they articulate significant physical, personal, and political hardships and melancholy.

This poem contains a number of amendments in three of the main hands present in the manuscript: the scribal hand, the hand likely to be Pulter’s own, and the “antiquarian hand” (see Ross (2000), pp. 150-171 and 252-4). For this reason, the poem makes an excellent case study in the editing processes evident in the manuscript. Only substantive amendments and editorial choices are outlined in the notes below.

app.rdg: My Soule why art thou ſad at the decay
My soul, why art thou sad at the decay
My soul, why art thou sad at the decay
Of this fraile frame this feeble houſe of clay

Of this frail framehere, structure, physical body, constitution, arrangement; may also signify universe, heavens, earth, or any part of it., this feeble house of claybody. See Isaiah 64:8: “O Lord, thou art our father; we are the clay, and thou our potter.”?
Of this frail frame, this feeble house of claythe body. See Isaiah 64:8, “O Lord, thou art our father; we are the clay, and thou our potter”.?
What can be expected from the humble birth
What can be expected from the humble birth
What can be expected from the humble birth
Of this fraile ffabrick but to fall to Earth
Of this frail fabricedifice, fabricated construction, but to fall to earth?
Of this frail fabric, but to fall to earth?
The Cristall^bubling fountaine being by Nature led
The bubbling fountain, being by nature led,
The bubblingThe scribal hand has scored out “crystal” and inserted “bubbling”. fountain, being by nature led,
Will riſe noe Higher then her Criſtall head
Will rise no higher than her crystal headproverbial: “no stream can rise higher than its source” (Eardley);
Will rise no higher than her crystal head;
Though many Marble Aquaductsor “Aquœducts” it fill
Though many marble aqueducts it fill,
Though many marble aqueducts it fill,
Yet in a conſtant level it runs ſtill
Yet in a constant level it runs still.
Yet in a constant level it runs still.
So Mortall Man even from his very birth
So mortal man, even from his very birth,
So mortal man, e’en from his very birth,
Runs weeping on, then creeps into the Earth
Runs weeping on, then creeps into the earth.
Runs weeping on, then creeps into the earth.
Thoſe gorgious flowers which the vallies Crown
Those gorgeous flowers which the valleys crown,
Those gorgeous flowers which the valleys crown,
That by the impartiall Siths \man \insertion written in hand H2. are moan down

That by the impartial scythemanmower who uses a sharp blade are mown down See Isaiah 40:6-8: “All flesh is grass, and all the goodliness thereof is as the flower of the field: The grass withereth, the flower fadeth: because the spirit of the Lord bloweth upon it: surely the people is grass. The grass withereth, the flower fadeth: but the word of our God shall stand forever.”:

That by the impartial scytheman“Scythes” in the scribal hand has had “man” added to it through an insertion in the hand likely to be Pulter’s own. As well as being a sharp, curved blade used to mow grass or other crops by hand, the scythe is commonly associated with Time and Death. are mown down,
Trust mee they ſeeme to hang theire heads and weep
Trust me, they seem to hang their heads and weep,
Trust me they seem to hang their heads and weep
Cauſe in theire ca^uſes they ſoe ſoone muſt ſleep
’Cause, in their causesoriginal, formative elements, they so soon must sleep.

’Cause in their causes“because in their causes”, with wordplay on Pulter’s distinctive use of the word “cause” in the second instance to mean the grave, connected to the elements or matter from which the body is first produced, and to which it returns in death. See OED cause n 5: the material cause is elements or matter from which a thing is produced; and the First Cause is the original cause or creator of the universe. See also lines 32, 46. they so soon must sleep.
Soe man to his first Principles must turn

So man to his first principlesorigins, constituent parts, primary propositions; in alchemy, the substances composing all matter (mercury, salt, and sulfur) must turnreturn; rotate; revolve; reverse course; become; make use of; change into,
So man to his first principlesthe fundamental sources from which something proceeds, primary elements (OED I.1b and II.3b) must turn
And take A Nap in Black oblivions Urn
And take a nap in black Oblivion’s urn.
And take a nap in black oblivion’s urn.
Triumphant Laurel whoſe unconquered bowes
Triumphant laurelfoliage of bay tree, whose unconquered boughs
Triumphant laurelIn ancient Greece and Rome, bay laurel wreaths were awarded as an emblem of military victory or of distinction in poetry., whose unconquered boughs
Encircles Poets, and the illustrious browes
Encircles poets’ and the illustrious brows
EncircleMS = Encircles poets, and the illustrious brows
Of Emperours: how ſoone alaſs wee ſee
Of emperorsWreaths of laurel were presented to victorious military leaders and poets in ancient Rome.: how soon, alas, we see
Of emperors: how soon, alas, we see

Her virgint^virginallin original “virginall”, descender of “g” struck through and ascender added to make “d”, with “all” covered by “L” in “Leaves; main scribe thus changed “virginall” to “virdent” or “virdent” by inserting “t” into space before “all”; “virgin” inserted in different hand from main scribe, with either looping insertion symbol or conversion of second “i” in “virginall” to “e” Leaves all fieldemort withered ^Fillimott directly below “fieldemort” and “Fillimott” above its second half, both in different hand from main scribe to bee

Her verdantIn the manuscript, various hands have inscribed this word differently so that it could be “virgin” (chaste), “virginal” (unsullied), or “verdant” (lushly green). leaves all withered filemotbrownish or yellowish color like that of a dead leaf, from the French “feuillemorte” to be.

HerThis line contains a number of amendments. The scribe has altered “virginall leaves” to “verdant leaves”, by altering and writing over letters in the main text. In an apparent misreading of priority, the “antiquarian hand” has written “virgin” above the altered word. The antiquarian has also annotated “fieldemort”, writing “Fillimott” above it—i.e. correctly understanding the word to be “filemot”. Beneath “fieldemort”, he has written “withered”, a definition of the word. verdant leaves all filemotthe colour of a dead or faded leaf (from the French feuillemorte) (OED) to be.
E’ne ſoe Mans youth and beauty “a” appears added later doth decay
E’en so, man’s youth and beauty doth decay,
E’en so man’s youth and beauty doth decay;

His in left margin, in hand H2: “X tho ſhe the liveing / kill and Dead preſrve / yett can she not / from death herſelfe reſerve”; horizontal line beneath, then: “The ſypriſs that / doth mourn for / us in vaine / ſhall bee cut down /and nevar ſprowt /againe.” heat and Moisture Cooles and dries to clay
His heat and moisture cools and dries to claySee note in line 2 on “clay.” Heat and moisture were chief properties of the body, as understood in classical humoral physiology..
His heat and moistureaccording to early modern humoural theory, these were two of the four qualities of the humoural body cools and dries to clay.
The stately Cedar that aſpires ſoe High

The stately cedarassociated with pride and great height. See Ezekiel 31:3-5: “Behold, the Assyrian was a cedar in Lebanon with fair branches, and with a shadowing shroud, and of an high stature; and his top was among the thick boughs. The waters made him great, the deep set him up on high with her rivers running round about his plants, and sent out her little rivers unto all the trees of the field. His height was exalted above all the trees of the field.” that aspires so high,
The stately cedarIn the Bible, the cedar is associated with great stature. See, for example, Amos 2:9 and Ezekiel 31:3-5. that aspires so high,
Scorning the cloudes threatning to Scale the Skie
Scorning the clouds, threat’ning to scale the sky,
Scorning the clouds, threat’ning to scale the sky,
ffor all her pride a kernill was her birth
For all her pride, a kernelseed was her birth,
For all her pride, a kernel was her birth,
Which Shewes at last ſhee must returne to Earth
Which shows, at last, she must return to earth.
Which shows at last she must return to earth;
Though she the living kill and dead preserveprotect; keep alive, retain; cedar oil was used in ancient Egypt to embalm corpses,

ThoughLines 27-30 have been added, in the margin, in the hand likely to be Pulter’s own. Their position for insertion is indicated with a small “x” above “So” at the beginning of line 31. she the living kill and dead preserve,
Yet can she not from death herself reserve.
Yet can she not from death herself reserve.
The cypresstree associated with grieving that doth mourn for us in vain
The cypressa tree traditionally associated with death and mourning (OED 1c). that doth mourn for us in vain
Shall be cut down and never sprout again.
Shall be cut down and never sprout again.
Sxoe“x” appears keyed to marginal note (see note 7) Man being tide to his Creatours lawes
So man, being tied to his Creator’s laws,
So man being tied to his creator’s laws
Must taste of Death and Shrinke unto his cauſe.
Must taste of death and shrink unto his cause.
Must taste of death and shrink unto his causeSee note to line 14..
The towering quick eyed Eagle that alone
The towering, quick-eyed eagle, that alone

The towering, quick-eyed eagleThe eagle was said to force its young to gaze upon the sun in order to determine their worthiness. See Philemon Holland’s translation of Pliny’s Natural History, a favourite source of Pulter’s, 1.272. that alone
Outfaces Phebus in his blazeing Throne
Outfacesboldly confronts, contradicts Phoebussun god in his blazing throne,
Outfaces PhoebusGreek god of the sun in his blazing throne,
And by that tryall bastard Birds diſclaime
And, by that trial, bastard birds disclaimAccording to legend, the eagle tests her young by having them look directly into the sun; those who fail are cast out of the nest.,
And by that trial, bastard birds disclaim,
Scorning they should be honoured with her name
Scorning they should be honored with her name;
Scorning they should be honoured with her name;
Yet ſhee and her’s to dust must all Resolve
Yet she and hers to dust must all resolveto dissolve or decompose; also with the connotation of bringing to a clear conclusion,
Yet she and hers to dust must all resolve,
And ſad obſcuritie must them involve.
And sad obscurity must them involveentangle, envelop.
And sad obscurity must them involve.
Soe miſerable Man doth draw his breath:
So miserable man doth draw his breath
So miserable man doth draw his breath
Twixt hope and feare then sinks into the Earth.
Twixt hope and fear, then sinks into the earth.
’Twixt hope and fear, then sinks into the earth.
The Phenix on her lofty Alter lies
The phoenix on her lofty altar lies

The phoenixThe phoenix is a mythical bird which burns itself to ashes on an aromatic funeral pyre ignited by the sun and fanned by its own wings. The bird then rises from its own ashes to live again, but Pulter’s focus here is on the self-immolation which makes this possible. See Holland (trans.), Pliny’s Natural History, p. 271. on her lofty altar lies
And Willingly a virgin victim dies
And willingly a virginpure, chaste victim dies;
And, willingly, a virgin victim dies,
Her Gold and purple Plums to Aſhes turns
Her gold and purple plumesfeathers to ashes turns
Her gold and purple plumes to ashes turns
As in her Aromatick Pier ſhee Burnes
As in her aromatic pyre she burnsthe phoenix, an Egyptian bird who burned in a sacrificial fire; a new phoenix was reborn from the ashes..
As in her aromatic pyre she burns.
Soe Man that to eternitie aſpiresFinal “e” imperfectly erased.
So man, that to eternity aspires,
So man that to eternity aspires,
Conquer’d by Death into his Cauſe Retires
Conquered by death, into his cause retires.
Conquered by death, into his causeSee note to line 14. retires.
The ſnowey Swan upon the[?] trembling brest,
The snowy swan upon the trembling breast

The snowy swanAccording to Ovid, the swan only sang once, when dying; the “swan-song” has become proverbial. For a similar image of the singing swan on the silver Thames, see The Invitation into the Country, lines 31-4; and see The Complaint of Thames, 1647, lines 100-104. upon the trembling breast
Of Silver Thames, how poore a time of Rest;
Of silver Thamesriver in England—how poor a time of rest
Of silver Thames, how poor a time of rest
Shee doth injoy, Soone droops her Milke white wings:
She doth enjoy—soon droops her milk-white wings,
She doth enjoy, soon droops her milk-white wings,
While ſadly Shee her Epicedium Sing’s.
While sadly she her epicediumfuneral ode singsAccording to Ovid, the swan sang only once, when dying..
While sadly she her epicediumfuneral ode sings.
Soe while man Strives t’eterniſe others glory:
So while man strives t’eternizeimmortalize others’ glory,
So while man strives t’eternise others’ glory,
Conſpireing Death, and time, cuts of his Story.
Conspiring Death and Time cuts off his storylife, account of life.
Conspiring Death and Time cutMS = “cuts” off his story.
The Stag that trips it or’e the Laun in State:
The stag that trips it o’er the lawn in stateA male deer prances (“trips it”) in a prosperous condition (“in state”),

The stagThe stag is a male deer, also used by Pulter (and other royalists) to represent Charles I. See the extended simile inserted into Upon the Death of my Dear and Lovely Daughter, Jane Pulter at lines 45-50. that trips it o’er the lawn in state,
Scorning the ground is Subject unto fate.
Scorning the ground, is subject unto fate.
Scorning the ground, is subject unto fate.
Even that brave heart which Blackmore once did hold
Even that brave hartdeer which Blackmorea valley in southern England once did hold,

E’en that brave hart which Blackmore once did holdCaesar was said to have put a collar around the neck of a deer with an inscription prohibiting its capture; it then lived to an extended age. The Vale of Blackmore, in Dorset, is where Caesar’s deer lived and was killed in some versions of the story. See Alice Eardley (ed.), Lady Hester Pulter: Poems, Emblems, and The Unfortunate Florinda (Toronto: Iter Inc. and Centre for Reformation and Restoration Studies, 2014), p. 67; and Michael Bath, “The Legend of Caesar’s Deer”, Medievalia et Humanistica, n.s., 9 (1979): 53-66. The best-known literary use of Caesar’s deer is in Thomas Wyatt’s sonnet, “Whoso list to hunt”.,
Whose Snowey neck incircled was with gold;
Whose snowy neck encircled was with gold,
Whose snowy neck encircled was with gold,
All Ages being deſired for Ceaſers ſake,
All ages being desired, for Caesar’s sake,
All ages being desired, for Caesar’s sake,
To ſpare his life when er’e they did him take:

To spare his life whene’er theyhunters did him takehunters throughout the ages were “desired” (here, required) to spare the deer’s life, out of respect for Caesar; Caesar’s deer reputedly lived for centuries.;
To spare his life whene’er they did him take,
but yet for all this Conquering Kings deſire,
But yet, for all this conquering king’s desire,
But yet for all this conquering king’s desire,
In teares hee did his vitall breath expire.

In tears hethe deer did his vital breath expireCaesar reputedly put ornamental collars on all his deer, which guaranteed their safety; Caesar’s last deer was killed in Blackmore, according to legend (Eardley); “hart” doubles for “heart” here..
In tears he did his vital breath expire.
Soe Man that enter’s in’s ſad Mothers fear’s:
So man, that enters in’sin his sad mother’s fears,
So man that enters in’s sad mother’s fears
As he begins, his Exit makes in teares.
As he begins, his exit makes: in tears.
As he begins, his exit makes in tears.
That beast which poiſonedcorrected over “poiſoning” Waters drink’s“k” written over earlier letter (possibly “ſ”), imperfectly erased with descender visible. with Scorn,
That beast which poisoned waters drinks with scorn,
That beastthe unicorn, whose horns were believed to have the power to purify water which poisoned waters drinks with scorn
Becauſe ſhee weares a Cordiall in her horne:
Because she wears a cordialrestorative medicine in her hornThe unicorn’s horn granted it the power to purify toxic waters.,
Because she wears a cordial in her horn,
ffrom putrefaction ſhee her being drew
From putrefactionrottenness, decay she her being drewAristotle posited that some life forms arose spontaneously from rotting matter.;

From putrefaction she her being drewAristotle argued in De Generatione et Corruptione that some creatures were born spontaneously out of the putrifying bodies of others. This is another image of potential rebirth out of death; however, as with the phoenix in lines 41-4, Pulter leaves this potential only implicit.;
Corruption then at least will haue his due.
Corruption, then, at last“least” in the manuscript, will have his due.
Corruption then at least will have his due.
Soe Man (a las) no cure can find in Death
So man (alas) no cure can find in death,
So man (alas) no cure can find in death,
When he that gave it takes away his breath
When He that gave it takes away hisman’s breath.
When he that gave it takes away his breath.
The King of Beasts that doth the forrest range,
The king of beastslion that doth the forest range,
The king of beastslion that doth the forest range,
And at his pleaſure doth his paſture Change:
And, at his pleasure, doth his pasture change,
And at his pleasure doth his pasture change,
And (like our Hidra) makes his will his laws

And (like our Hydrahere, Pulter’s view of the tyranny of the commonwealth government, derived from the multi-headed mythological water snake killed by Hercules; when one head was struck off, two shot up in its place.) makes his will his laws,

And, like our Hydra in Greek mythology, a many-headed monster whose heads grow again as fast as they are cut off. Pulter uses the Hydra as a figure for Cromwell and the corruption she sees as associated with his rule. See The Invitation into the Country, line 4., makes his will his laws,
Tearing his vaſſals w:th his Cruill clawes
Tearing his vassalssubordinates, slaves with his cruel claws,
Tearing his vassals with his cruel claws;
As other creatures hath his Terrour felt
As other creatures hath his terror felt,
As other creatures hath his terror felt,
Soe Death will doe by him as he hath dealt
So Death will do by him, as he hath dealt.
So death will do by him as he hath dealt.
Soe domineering Man his Trophis must
So domineering man, his trophiesvictories, tokens of victory must
So domineering man, his trophies must
Ere long bee read and ſeene in Nought but dust
Ere long be readdiscerned, interpreted and seen in naught but dust.
Ere long be read and seen in nought but dust.
That huge Laviathan that playes and sportes
That huge leviathanenormous sea creature, whale that plays and sports

That huge leviathanaquatic animal (real or imaginary) of enormous size, frequently mentioned in Hebrew poetry; see Job 41:1-33. Pulter (as is common) conflates the leviathan and the whale. See also Pulter’s This Vast Leviathan (Emblem 12). that plays and sports
And makes mad Reax in Neptunes Azure courts
And makes mad reaks in Neptune’s azure courtsundertakes pranks (“reaks”) in the Roman god of water’s (“Neptune’s”) blue (“azure”) waves,
And makes mad rexpranks, playful tricks. in Neptune’sRoman god of the sea. azure courts,
Even he whose fellow was by fates direction
E’en he, whose fellowkin was, by fate’s direction,

E’en he whose fellow was by Fate’s direction A story from Jewish lore of two whales, male and female, castrated and pickled respectively by God to prevent them reproducing and causing widespread destruction Alice Eardley (ed.), Lady Hester Pulter: Poems, Emblems, and The Unfortunate Florinda (Toronto: Iter Inc. and Centre for Reformation and Restoration Studies, 2014), p. 68.).
ffain’d to be powd’rd gainst the Reſurrection

Feignedimagined to be powdered ’gainst the ResurrectionEardley cites Jewish lore, which tells of how God sought to prevent the reproduction of whales by pickling (or powdering) the female to serve as food for the righteous in eternity; the afterlife is what surpasses the Resurrection (God’s final judgment at the end of the world).,
Feignedfabled to be powderedsalted, pickled for future use; preserved. ’gainstin preparation for. the resurrection,
That ſom[?]end of word unclear, with apparently later addition of what looks like “a”, possibly part of malformed “n” of Pride on the forſaken Shores

That son of prideSee Job 41:33-34, referring to the leviathan or whale: “Upon earth there is not his like, who is made without fear. / He beholdeth all high things: he is a king over all the children of pride.” on the forsaken shores,
That son of Pridethe whale, described in the Bible as “a king over all the children of pride” (Job 41:34). See also Pulter’s This Vast Leviathan" (Emblem 12), line 9. on the forsaken shores,
Out of his Eliment his life out Rores
Out of his element, his life outroarsdrowns out, throws into confusion.

Out of his element his life out roarsPulter’s meaning here is not “outroar”, a single word meaning to roar louder than (OED v). Rather, she means that the leviathan roars his life out (and in doing so expires). For a similarly distinctive usage, see The Invitation into the Country, in which the Thames “her loss deplores / And to the sea her grief out roars” (lines 29-30); and see The Complaint of Thames, 1647, line 98: “I will roar out my grief unto the main”..
Soe Man though hee all Creatures elce tranſcend
So man, though he all creatures else transcend
So man, though he all creatures else transcend,
In Sighs and Groanes, (ah mee) his life must end
In sighs and groans (ah me!), his life must end.
In sighs and groans (ah me) his life must end.
The Swiftest Creature that’s below the Moone
The swiftest creaturedolphin that’s below the moon,
The swiftest creaturethe dolphin that’s below the moon,
Which ſav’d Orions life (alas) how ſoone
Which saved Arion’s lifeArion, a musician/poet in ancient Greece who was kidnapped by pirates and rescued by dolphins (alas), how soon

Which saved Arion’sMS = Orion’s. A Greek lyric poet and harpist, borne to safe land on a dolphin after being thrown overboard by Corinthian sailors. See Katherine Philips’s use of the Arion story to celebrate Charles II’s restoration to the monarchy, “Arion on a Dolphin, to His Majesty in his Passage into England”. life, alas how soonMS = Which saved Orion’s life (alas) how soon. In modernising the punctuation of this line, I have attached the expostulation “alas” to “how soon her race will end” rather than to “saved Arion’s life”. For alternative modernisations of the punctuation of this line, see Leah Knight and Wendy Wall’s Elemental Edition of the poem, and Alice Eardley (ed.), Lady Hester Pulter: Poems, Emblems, and The Unfortunate Florinda (Toronto: Iter Inc. and Centre for Reformation and Restoration Studies, 2014).
Her Race will [ev]“e” or “ev,” scribbled out end even in A little time
Her racevoyage or progress through life; contest of speed; also, species will end; even in a little time
Her race will end; e’en in a little time
Shee must returne againe to dirt or Slime
She must return again to dirt or slime.
She must return again to dirt or slime.
Soe Man his Destinie can ner’e out run
So man, his destiny can ne’er outrun,
So man his destiny can ne’er outrun;
The cruell Parce cuts, Mans life is dun
The cruel Parcaethree Fates who determine length of human lives by cutting threads cuts: man’s life is done.
The cruel Parcaein Roman mythology, the three Fates, usually depicted as three women who draw forth, measure out, and cut the threads of human life. cutMS = “cuts”, man’s life is done.
The little Remmora that nere will fayle
The little remorasuckerfish that can attach to anything in the water and, in legends, could impede their movement; obstacle that ne’er will fail

The little remoraa little fish that attaches itself to the underside of ships, slowing its passage or preventing it entirely from moving (commonly used figuratively or emblematically). See the description in Holland’s translation of Pliny’s Natural History, 2.425. that ne’er will fail
To stop the Proudest Ship thats under Sayle
To stop the proudest ship that’s under sail,
To stop the proudest ship that’s under sail,
When Death doth summon her Shee must away
When Death doth summon her, she must away;
When Death doth summon her she must away;
ffor all her Art Shee cant make time to Stay
For all her art, she can’t make time to stayhalt, support.
For all her art she can’t make time to stay.
So Man that Strives to blurr anothers fame
So man, that strives to blurblemish another’s fame,
So man that strives to blur another’s fame,
Death comes the while and blots out his own name
Death comes the whilemeanwhile and blotsstains, disfigures in ink out his own name.
Death comes the while and blots out his own name.
Those Cittyes that the Orient kingdoomes gracest
Those cities that the orienteastern kingdoms gracesthonors,
Those cities that the orient kingdoms gracest,
Beneath theere Ruins (Sadly) li’es defacest
Beneath their ruins (sadly) lies defacest:
Beneath their ruins, sadly, lies defacest,
As Ninnivie Perſepoles, the faire
AsSuch as Nineveh, Persepolis the fair,
As Ninevehan ancient Assyrian city founded by Nimrod (Genesis 10:11)., Persepolisthe ceremonial capital of the Achaemenid Empire, in ancient Persia. the fair,
And Babilon (Soe famous) all deſpaire

And BabylonBabylon, in ancient Mesopotamia (now Iraq), like Nineveh, in Assyria (now Iraq) and Persepolis, in ancient Persia (now Iran), referred to in the previous line, were ancient towns that were destroyed (so famous!), all despair
And Babylonancient city on the River Euphrates, in Mesopotamia, famous for its monumental buildings and hanging gardens so famous, all despair
Of ever being Reſtored againe, and now
Of ever being restored again; and now
Of ever being restored again, and now
Wee ſee that all to time and fate muſt bow
We see that all to time and fate must bow.
We see that all to time and fate must bow.
Soe wretched Man whoſe Structure is of dust

So wretched man, whose structure is of dustsee Genesis 2:7: “And the Lord God formed man [of] the dust of the ground, and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life; and man became a living soul.”,
So wretched man, whose structure is of dust,
After his periods past he moulder must
After his period’stime’s past, he molderdisintegrate must,
After his period’s past, he moulder must,
And this our Globe of Earth er’e long Shall burn
And this, our globe of earth, erebefore long shall burn,
And this our globe of earth ere long shall burn
And all her pomp and Pride to ^ Cinders Ashes turn

And all her pomp and pride to cindersThe manuscript reads “ashes,” with “cinders” inserted above by the main scribe; given the poem’s meter, it seems likely that the scribe omitted to strike out “ashes” after replacing it. turntransform, return.

And all her pomp and pride to ashesThe scribe has added “cinders” above this word; a caret indicates the insertion, but “ashes” has not been scored out, and no priority has been indicated between the two alternatives. turn.
Then my impatiant Soule what cans’t thou Say
Then, my impatient soul, what canst thou say,
Then, my impatient soul, what canst thou say,
Seeing all Sublunary things decay
Seeing all sublunaryearthly (beneath the moon), minor things decay?
Seeing all sublunarybeneath the moon; i.e. earthly, belonging to this world things decay?
Nay mark Aurora in her youthfull pride
Nay, mark Auroragoddess of dawn, in her youthful pride,
Nay, mark AuroraRoman goddess of the dawn (and the subject of several poems by Pulter) in her youthful pride,
Her purple Curtains newly drawn aſide
Her purple curtains newly drawn aside,
Her purple curtains newly drawn aside,
As when her bleſſed Infant Shee brought forth
As when her blesséd infant she brought forth,
As when her blessed infant she brought forth,
The faire Astrea of unparreld worth
The fair Astraeagoddess of justice, whom Pulter identifies as well with truth; daughter of Aurora of unparalleled worth.
The fair Astraeain Roman mythology, daughter of Aurora and Astraeus, and the goddess of truth or justice. of unparalledunparalleled, a contraction common in Pulter’s poems. worth.
Bright is the one but brighter is the other
Bright is the one, but brighter is the other;
Bright is the one, but brighter is the other;
The Daughter infinitely excels the Mother
The daughter infinitely excels the mother.
The daughter infinitely excels the mother.
Light from mine eyes I wiſh may never part
Light from mine eyes, I wish may never part,
Light from mine eyes I wish may never part,
But thou Sweete Truth Shalt harbor in my heart
But thou, sweet Truth, shalt harbor in my heart.
But thou, sweet Truth, shalt harbour in my heart;
Yet this most glorious Creature light Soone fades
Yet this most glorious creature, Light, soon fades
Yet this most glorious creature, Light, soon fades
And is inveloped in nights darke Shades
And is enveloped in night’s dark shades.
And is enveloped in night’s dark shades.
Soe though Mans Soule’s a beame of Heavenly light
So though man’s soul’s a beam of heavenly light,
So, though man’s soul’s a beam of heavenly light,
Yet must his body Sleepe in Death and Night
Yet must his body sleep in death and night.
Yet must his body sleep in death and night.
Nay Cinthias borrowed Splendencencie Shall ceaſe
Nay, Cynthia’sthe moon’s borrowed splendencysplendor shall cease,
Nay, Cynthia’san epithet of Artemis, the Greek goddess of the moon. borrowed splendencythe moon reflects the light of the sun shall cease,
And Shee Shall leave to wane and to increase
And she shall leavecease to wane and to increase;
And she shall leavecease to wane and to increase,
Nor shall her changes make ^o:r our“our” appears above “o:r” (which has superscript “r”); insertions appear to be in two hands, each different from main scribe Ocean Riſe
Nor shall her changes make our ocean rise
Nor shall her changes make our ocean rise
Or fall, or her Sad influence cloſe our eyes
Or fall, or her sad influence close our eyes.
Or fall, or her sad influence close our eyes.
Hers and her Brothers firery Shafts noe more
Hers and her brother’sApollo’s (the sun god’s) fiery shafts no more

rdg.seg: Her and her brother’s fiery shafts no moreMS = Hers. The fiery shafts of Artemis, and her brother Apollo, the Greek god of the sun

app.rdg: Shall make poore Niobies theire loſs deplore

Shall make poor Niobessiblings Apollo and Cynthia (Artemis) transformed Niobe into a weeping rock for bragging that she had more children than their mother; here, the sun and moon, which Pulter imagines as continuously spurring all grieving mothers (figuratively, “Niobes”) to mourn their losses, will disappear and no longer exert influence. their loss deplore.

Shall make poor Niobesin Greek mythology, Artemis and Apollo punished Niobe, who had boasted of having more children than their mother, Leto. Artemis and Apollo killed Niobe’s children and transformed her into a weeping stone. Niobe became a common literary figure for a woman’s profound grief for her children. See Upon the Death of my Dear and Lovely Daughter, Jane Pulter, line 50. their loss deplore.
The glittering harbinger of Cheerfull Day
The glitt’ring harbingerforerunner of cheerful dayAurora, goddess of dawn,
The glittering harbingerAurora, goddess of the dawn (harbinger: one that goes before) of cheerful day
That leads the Sable Empris on her way
That leads the sable EmpressNight on her way,
That leads the sable empressnight on her way,
Bearing a Torch her Ebone Coach beſide
Bearing a torch her ebonblack coach beside,
Bearing a torch, her eboni.e. ebony (black) coach beside,
As shee Triumphant round our Orb doth ride
As she, triumphant, round our orbEarth doth ride,
As she triumphant round our orb doth ride,
E’ne Shee [?]strike-through of complete word, starting “A” and ending “ſed” shall bee \amaz’d \written in hand H2 and lose her way
E’en she shall be amazedbewildered, astonished and lose her way,

E’enThis line has been amended. Originally “E’en she a[..s.d] shall be, and lose her way”, the word beginning with “a” (possibly “abused”?) has been scored out, and “amazed” has been added above the line to create “E’en she shall be amazed, and lose her way”. The word “amazed” is in the hand likely to be Pulter’s own, suggesting this is an authorial amendment. she shall be amazedbewildered, confounded, perplexed; also terror-stricken (OED 2 and 3), and lose her way,
Not able to conduct the Night or Day
Not able to conduct the night or day.
Not able to conduct the night or day.
Nor Shall that Slie the^ife, Hermes, ever keepe
Nor shall that sly thief Hermes ever keepconfine himself, remain,

Nor shall that sly thief, HermesHermes is Mercury, the planet closest to the sun, and therefore very difficult for astronomers to see behind the “illustrious sunbeams”. Here he is depicted as playing bo-peep, a nursery game of hiding one’s face and suddenly reappearing (OED)., ever keep
Behind the illuſtrious Sun beams playing bopeep
Behind th’illustrious sun beams, playing bo peep;
Behind th’illustrious sunbeams, playing bo-peep;
His light shall bee obſcured noe more with light
His light shall be obscured no more with light,
His light shall be obscured no more with light,
But all his Knaveries Shall come in Sight

But all his knaveriesmischiefs shall come in sightHermes, or Mercury, is both the trickster messenger god and the planet Mercury, which is hidden by the sun, seeming to play a nursery game of hide and seek..
But all his knaveriestrickeries shall come in sight.
The ffount and Center of all Light the Sun
The fountsource, fountain and center of all light, the sun,
The fount and centre of all light, the sun,
Round whom whoſe“w” possibly corrected to “t” in different hand from main scribe Orbs perpetually doe run
Round whom those orbsplanets perpetually do run,
Round whom thoseOriginally “whose”, the word may have been corrected, through an adjustment of the “w”, to “those” (a better word here). orbs perpetually do run,
Shall all his influence and ^light contract
Shall all his influence and light contract,
Shall all his influence and light contract,
Which will Amazed Nature quite diſtract
Which will amazéd Nature quite distract.
Which will amazèdsee note to line 131; or here, perhaps, lost in wonder and astonishment (OED 4) Nature quite distract.
Auſpitious Jupiter poore Mortals friend

Auspicious JupiterJupiter, the largest planet and supreme god in Roman pantheon, is seen, in astrology, as “auspicious” (presenting a positive omen), temperate, wise, benevolent, and concerned with law and judgement, with tacit affiliations to Christian judgement in art., poor mortal’s friend,

Auspicious JupiterJupiter is the largest planet in the solar system and the supreme Roman god. In astrological terms, the planet is “auspicious”, a sign that good things will happen., poor mortals’ friend,
His mild Aspect to earth noe more Shall Send
His mild aspect to earth no more shall send.
His mild aspect to earth no more shall send;
ffierce Mars imperfectly blotted “e” afterward his flagrant rapeire Shall put up
Fierce Marsgod of war his flagrant rapierblazing sword shall put up,
Fierce Mars the planet associated with the god of war., his flagrant rapierblazing, burning sword. shall put up lay aside.,
Seing totall Nature drinks the Selfe Same cup
Seeing total Nature drinks the selfsameidentical cup
Seeing total Nature drinks the self-same cup;
And that Malignant Melancholy Star
And that malignant, melancholy starSaturn
And that malignant, melancholy starSaturn, which has a long astrological association with melancholy
That to doe miſchiefe could diſcerne ſoe fare
That, to do mischief, could discernsee, perceive so far
That, to do mischief, could discern so far
As sweete Hibernie“ni” overwrites an unknown letter Where Iappears crowded between surrounding words first had life
As sweet Hibernieclassical name for Ireland where I first had lifePulter was born outside of Dublin.,

As sweet Hibernie, where I first had lifePulter was born in Ireland, the classical Latin name for which is Hibernia. Here, she describes Saturn as presiding over her birth even in Ireland. She frequently refers in her poetry to the influence of melancholic Saturn on her life and character. See Alice Eardley, “Saturn (whose aspects soe sads my soul)”: Lady Hester Pulter’s Feminine Melancholic Genius”, in Michael Denbo (ed.), New Ways of Looking at Old Texts, IV: Papers of the Renaissance English Text Society, 2002-2006 (Tempe, AZ: ACMRS, 2008), pp. 239-252.,
Now quite destroyed by Atropus Keene Knife
Now quite destroyed by Atropos’sone of the three Fates’ keensharp knife.
Now quite destroyed by Atropos’one of the three Fates (or Parcae, line 90), she who cuts the thread of mortal life keen knife.
Ah cruell stars not mee alone anoy
Ah, cruel stars, not me alone annoy,
Ah, cruel stars not me alone annoy,
But my poore Countrey too they must destroy
But my poor country too, theythe stars must destroy.
But my poor country, too, they must destroy!
But those conjunctions too er’e long Shall ceaſe
But those conjunctionsalignments of the stars too ere long shall cease;
But those conjunctionsalignments of the stars, too, ere long shall cease,
When Alls“A” overwrites “ſt” to Chaos turnd there will be peace
When all’s to chaos turned, there will be peace.
When all’s to chaos turned, there will be peace.
The Six proud Pleads Shall theire bevty hide

The six proud Pleiadescluster of stars in the constellation Taurus, of which only six are visible; in mythology, seven virgin followers of the goddess Artemis, whom Zeus turned into stars to protect them from the sexual advances of Orion shall their beauty hide,

The six proud PleiadsThe Pleiades are a prominent cluster of stars in the constellation Taurus, often referred to as seven (or “the seven sisters”) even though only six are easily visible to the naked eye. These six are the “proud” (splendid, standing out) Pleiades which Pulter imagines becoming dark. shall their beauty hide,
As well as Sissiphus his baſhfull Bride

As well as Sisyphus his bashful brideMerope, a nearly invisible star in the Pleiades (see note on “Pleiades,” line 153); she hides her face for shame at having married a mortal, while all her sisters mated with gods; wife of Sisyphus, condemned eternally to push a rock up a hill and have it roll back before he reached the summit.

As well as Sisyphus, his bashful brideMerope, the nearly invisible star in the Pleaides (see note above), who hides her face in shame at having married a mortal (Sisyphus), while all her sisters mated with gods;
Then Shall Orions Harpe noe Muſick make
Then shall Orion’sconflating Orion, a giant hunter turned into a constellation, with musician Arion (see note on Parcae) harp no music make,

Then shall Orion’sin Greek mythology, a giant and huntsman transformed at his death into a constellation of stars. Pulter here conflates him with the Greek lyric poet and harpist Arion (see note to line 86). harp no music make,
But ſuch as Shall the Stoutest Courage Shake
But such as shall the stoutestproudest, fiercest courage shake.
But such as shall the stoutest courage shake;
Thoſe tender hearted Siſters Shall noe more

Those tenderhearted sistersthe Hyades (or the “rainers”), seven nymphs who wept at the death of their brother, Hyas, so much that Zeus turned then into a constellation, which appears in rainy seasons. shall no more
Those tender-hearted sistersthe Hyades, sisters in Greek mythology to the Pleiades and the Hesperides shall no more
Theire brother Hilas hasty fate deplore
Their brother Hyas’s hasty fate deplore,

Their brother Hyas’ hasty fate deploreMS = Hilas. In Greek mythology, the Hyades are “the rainy ones”; they were seven nymphs who wept so much at the death of their brother, Hyas, that Zeus turned them into a constellation, which appears in rainy seasons.,
Sho^wreing from theire Sad eyes Such floods of Rain
Showering from their sad eyes such floods of rain
Show’ring from their sad eyes such floods of rain
That oft the plowmans hopes and labour’s vaine
That oft the plowman’s hopes and labor’s vain.
That oft the plowman’s hopes and labour’si.e. labour is vain.
The Vulture that did Stop Mans high deſigne
The vultureconstellation Lyra that shines from the sky and is represented as a bird, either eagle or vulture (Eardley); creature who gnawed on Prometheus’s liver that did stop man’s high design,
The vultureone of two northern constellations, Lyra or Aquila that did stop man’s high design
Must stoope to fate and ceaſe to fly ^or [ag]ſhine initial “a” scribbled out; “g” written over with “ſ”; “h” writes over another “a”, correcting “againe” to “ſhine”
Must stoop to fate and cease to fly or shine.
Must stoop to fate and cease to fly or shineamended from “again”, in the scribal hand,
And all the Gems of Ariadnas Crown
And all the gems of Ariadne’s crownAbandoned by Theseus, after she helped him kill the Minotaur, Ariadne is transformed by Dionysius into a constellation crowned by seven stars.
And all the gems of Ariadne’sin Greek mythology, a consort of Theseus and Dionysus, who transforms here into a constellation crowned by seven stars crown
Shall loſe theire (Sparkling) luster & drop down
Shall lose their sparkling luster and drop down.
Shall lose their sparkling lustre and drop down.
Nor Shall pale Aſaph evermore apeare
Nor shall pale Asophcomet visible every 400 years evermore appear
Nor shall pale Asopha comet thought to appear every 400 years. evermorefor all future time appear
At the Revolving of fowre Hundred yeare
At the revolving of four hundred year;
At the revolving of four hundred year,
ffor though her abſence wee have long indur’d
For though her absence we have long endured,
For though her absence we have long endured,
Yet Shall Shee bee eternally obſcur’d
Yet shall she be eternally obscured.
Yet shall she be eternally obscured.
Bold Syrius no more Shall Shew her face
Bold SiriusDog Star, appearing in hot summer no more shall show her face,

Bold Siriusthe Dog Star, one of the brightest stars in the sky. In ancient times, the rising of the Dog Star was associated with the hottest, most sultry days of summer (“dog days”). no more shall show her face,
As Shee doth uſe when Phebus is in place
As she doth use when Phoebus is in place.
As she doth useusually does when Phoebusthe Greek god of the sun is in place,
But these and all the fixed Orbs of light
But these, and all the fixéd orbs of light,
But these and all the fixèd orbs of light
Shall bee involv’d once more in Horred night
Shall be involved once more in horrid night.
Shall be involvedenveloped once more in horrid night.
Like Robes the Elements Shall folded liecorrected from “bee”
Like robes, the elementsbasic substances of which all material bodies are composed; in ancient philosophy, believed to be earth, water, air, and fire. shall folded lie
Like robes, the elements shall folded lie
In the vast wardrope of eternitie
In the vast wardrobe of eternity.
In the vast wardrobe of eternity.
Then my unſetled ſoule bee more reſolv’d
Then my unsettled soul, be more resolveddisintegrated; convinced,
Then my unsettled soul be more resolved,
Se’eing all this Univerſe must be diſſolv’d.
Seeing all this universe must be dissolvedSee first note..
Seeing all this universe must be dissolvedSee note to Title..
